cards.title: Rugby World Cup / Prince Harry and Jonny Wilkinson launch trophy tour
cards.rawTitle: Prince Harry and Jonny Wilkinson launch trophy tour

item.title: Prince Harry and Jonny Wilkinson launch Rugby World Cup trophy tour
item.trailText: With 100 days to go until the start of the 2015 Rugby World Cup, the tournament's trophy is sent off on a tour, beginning at Twickenham Stadium
item.standFirst: With 100 days to go until the start of the 2015 Rugby World Cup, the tournament's trophy is sent off on a tour, beginning at Twickenham Stadium on Wednesday. Visiting some 300 events in the United Kingdom and Ireland, the trophy will stay on the road until England meets Fiji on 18 September

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for Prince Harry and Jonny Wilkinson launch Rugby World Cup trophy tour  - video Photograph: guardian.co.uk

cards.title: NBA finals / James on Cavaliers’ Game Three win over Golden State
cards.rawTitle: James on Cavaliers’ Game Three win over Golden State

item.title: NBA finals: LeBron James on Cleveland Cavaliers’ victory over Golden State Warriors
item.trailText: Cleveland Cavaliers LeBron James appears nonchalant after his performance against the Golden State Warriors helped his team win Game 3 in the NBA finals
item.standFirst: Cleveland Cavaliers LeBron James appears nonchalant after his performance against the Golden State Warriors helped his team win Game 3 in the NBA finals. James, who says he is doing everything possible for his team, contributed 40 points, 12 rebounds and eight assists in the game on Tuesday. Winning 96-91, the Cavs now lead the series 2-1

cards.title: Football / 'If we didn't qualify for Italia '90 where would US soccer be?'
cards.rawTitle: 'If we didn't qualify for Italia '90 where would US soccer be?'

item.title: 'If we didn't qualify for the '90 World Cup where would US soccer be?'
item.trailText: Twenty-five years ago today, the US played their first game at the 1990 World Cup: they lost 5-1 to Czechoslovakia
item.standFirst: Twenty-five years ago today, the US played their first game at the 1990 World Cup: they lost 5-1 to Czechoslovakia. But the US's first trip to a World Cup for 40 years helped revive the sport in America and set up the foundations for future success
item.byline: Les Carpenter, Laurence Mathieu-Leger and Corentin Soibinet

cards.title: Nothing but net? / Andy Murray attempts NBA Halfcourt challenge
cards.rawTitle: Andy Murray attempts NBA Halfcourt challenge

item.title: Andy Murray attempts NBA Halfcourt challenge
item.trailText: Andy Murray fails to hit all five of his shots in the NBA Halfcourt challenge
item.standFirst: Andy Murray fails to hit all five of his shots in the NBA Halfcourt challenge. Murray, wearing a Miami Heat jersey, rims out several attempts before conceding defeat. Other athletes to complete the challenge include Gareth Bale, who made three of his attempts. Murray nominates Serena Williams for the next Halfcourt challenge

cards.title: Women's World Cup / Opening round of group stage matches
cards.rawTitle: Opening round of group stage matches

item.title: Women's World Cup 2015: opening round of matches
item.trailText: We round up the best photos from the opening round of matches in the group stage of the Women’s World Cup in Canada
item.standFirst: We round up the best photos from the opening round of matches in the group stage of the Women’s World Cup in Canada

displayImages.caption: The hosts Canada get the World Cup underway against China. The game was watched by more than 53,000 inside the Commonwealth Stadium in Edmonton, making it the best attended match in Canadian women’s football history Photograph: Jeff McIntosh/AP
displayImages.altText: The hosts Canada get the World cup underway against China. The game was watched by more than 53,000 inside the Commonwealth Stadium in Edmonton, making it the best attended match in Canadian women’s football history.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The hosts Canada get the World Cup underway against China. The game was watched by more than 53,000 inside the Commonwealth Stadium in Edmonton, making it the best attended match in Canadian women’s football history

displayImages.caption: China’s Ying Li is tackled by Canada’s Kadeisha Buchanan Photograph: Dan Riedlhuber/EPA
displayImages.altText: Ying Li is tackled by Kadeisha Buchanan.
displayImages.cleanCaption: China’s Ying Li is tackled by Canada’s Kadeisha Buchanan

displayImages.altText: Christine Sinclair scores an injury-time penalty, winning the game for Canada 1-0.

displayImages.cleanCaption: A referee uses vanishing spray to mark a free-kick for Holland during their match against New Zealand. The Dutch team took the points after a stunning first-half strike from Lieke Martens, winning 1-0 in Edmonton

displayImages.caption: Brazil’s Marta greets the escort children in the tunnel before their 2-0 win over South Korea in Montreal. The legendary five-time world player of the year scored Brazil’s second with a penalty in the 53rd minute, giving her a record 15 career World Cup goals and surpassing the 14 gscored by Germany’s Birgit Prinz Photograph: Stuart Franklin/FIFA via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Brazil’s Marta greets the escort children in the players tunnel ahead of their 2-0 win over South Korea.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Brazil’s Marta greets the escort children in the tunnel before their 2-0 win over South Korea in Montreal. The legendary five-time world player of the year scored Brazil’s second with a penalty in the 53rd minute, giving her a record 15 career World Cup goals and surpassing the 14 gscored by Germany’s Birgit Prinz
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Stuart Franklin/FIFA via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Mexico’s goalkeeper Cecilia Santiago punches the ball away as her team-mates Nayeli Rangel, second left, Christina Murillo and Colombia’s Natalia Gaitan, right, battle for the ball in Moncton. Colombia came from behind to salvage a late draw with a thumping shot from outside the area Photograph: Cj Gunther/EPA
displayImages.altText: Mexico’s goalkeeper Cecilia Santiago punches the ball away as Mexico’s Nayeli Rangel, second left, Christina Murillo and Colombia’s Natalia Gaitan, right, battle for the ball.

The legendary five-time world player of the year scored Brazil’s second with a penalty in the 53rd minute, giving her a record 15 career World Cup goals and surpassing the 14 gscored by Germany’s Birgit Prinz
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Stuart Franklin/FIFA via Getty Images

image.caption: Mexico’s goalkeeper Cecilia Santiago punches the ball away as her team-mates Nayeli Rangel, second left, Christina Murillo and Colombia’s Natalia Gaitan, right, battle for the ball in Moncton. Colombia came from behind to salvage a late draw with a thumping shot from outside the area Photograph: Cj Gunther/EPA
image.altText: Mexico’s goalkeeper Cecilia Santiago punches the ball away as Mexico’s Nayeli Rangel, second left, Christina Murillo and Colombia’s Natalia Gaitan, right, battle for the ball.

item.trailText: Team USA’s tournament got off to the perfect start at the Women’s World Cup in Winnipeg yesterday. Here’s a roundup of fans’ photos from the 3-1 win
item.standFirst: Team USA’s tournament got off to the perfect start at the Women’s World Cup in Winnipeg yesterday. Here’s a roundup of fans’ photos from the 3-1 win
item.body: Team USA kicked off their World Cup campaign with a 3-1 win over Australia on Monday evening. Here’s a roundup of fans’ photos from the impressive victory.

cards.title: Extreme sports / Kingston climbs top of Wembley arch
cards.rawTitle: Kingston climbs top of Wembley arch

item.title: Don't look down! James Kingston climbs top of Wembley Stadium arch
item.trailText: James Kingston becomes the first to climb to the top of Wembley Stadium's arch
item.standFirst: James Kingston becomes the first to climb to the top of Wembley Stadium's arch. In an advert by EE, the 24-year-old free-runner is seen balancing himself while walking on the arch, some 440 feet above the Wembley pitch. In 2014, Kingston was arrested in Dubai after scaling the second largest building in the country
